newsitem.title: ITALY: TENNIS-SPANISH SEEDS FORGE AHEAD AS HUBER FALLS/RPT.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-SPANISH SEEDS FORGE AHEAD AS HUBER FALLS/RPT.

text.p: The Spanish seeds enjoyed a quiet evening stroll into the third round of the Italian Open women's tennis tournament on Wednesday as Germany's fourth seed Anke Huber fell sick and lost to a teenage wild card.

Conchita Martinez, champion at the Foro Italico for a record four years in succession, swept past American Chanda Rubin 6-2 6-3 in a floodlit match on a chilly centre court to set up a clash with Russian 12th seed Elena Likhovtseva.
"I didn't give her too many opportunities, I changed the rhythm playing high and low balls and that is it," she said in an accurate summation of her hour on court.

Former world number one and second seed Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, a late entry to the tournament, earlier reached the last 16 -- where she meets Belgium's 13th seed Sabine Appelmans -- by blasting aside Argentine Paola Suarez 6-2 6-2.
While the top two seeds in action barely worked up a sweat, three others including 1996 Australian Open finalist Huber failed to progress beyond the second round.
Huber was the biggest shock, losing to 19-year-old 73rd-ranked Italian Francesca Lubiani 6-2 6-4.
The surprise was dimmed somewhat when it later emerged that the German was suffering from gastritis.

A WTA statement said that Huber, who withdrew from the doubles tournament where she had been due to partner world number three Monica Seles, had suffered a stomach ache, headache and nausea that came on during practice.
It said she was returning to her home in Austria.
Huber did not attend a post-match news conference but made clear that she had been way below her best.
"I don't want to take anything away from her but I haven't been playing well for some time now," she said.
"This is not the way I play tennis. I really don't know what else to say about my game today."
Huber had staged a brief comeback in her second set, pulling back from 5-1 down to 5-4 before giving in.
Her already erratic serve deserted her and, with Lubiani enjoying two match points, she hastened the end by double-faulting into the net.
"Its the most important win of my career," said the Bolognese winner, who is coached by her father and now meets Austrian 11th seed Barbara Paulus.
"I knew she was the most erratic of the top 10, the most beatable, I knew I could win."
The other seeds to fall, after the departure on Tuesday of 15th-seeded Frenchwoman Nathalie Tauziat, were France's Sandrine Testud and Brenda Schultz McCarthy of the Netherlands.
Sixteenth seed Testud lost 7-6 6-0 to Switzerland's Patty Schnyder while ninth seed Schultz went out to South African Joannette Kruger 6-2 7-5.
There was little real threat to the remaining seeds in action although some had a few problems on the way.

Romanian Ruxandra Dragomir lost her first set to Belgian Els Callens while Croatia's fifth seed Iva Majoli was taken to three sets by American qualifier Nicole Arendt, who needed a massage to her right thigh while ahead 2-1 in the third set.
Dragomir won 3-6 6-2 6-0 and now faces Majoli.
France's Mary Pierce beat American Ann Grossman 6-2 6-2 and now meets top seed Seles on Thursday.
South African sixth seed Amanda Coetzer sent 15-year-old Russian Anna Kournikova out of the tournament after also dropping a set to the crowd favourite. REUTER
